intro: Brunellia farallonensis, commonly known as the Farallon Island hibiscus, is a flowering plant native to the Galápagos Islands. It belongs to the family Malvaceae and is characterized by its woody structure and showy, five-petaled flowers. The plant typically grows in coastal areas, thriving in the humid and saline conditions of its native habitat. Its leaves are ovate to elliptical in shape, with a smooth or slightly hairy surface. The species is notable for its ecological role in supporting local insect and bird populations.
